title: Deprecate `**kwargs` in `st.plotly_chart` and add `config` instead

labels.name: type:enhancement
labels.description: Requests for feature enhancements or new features

body:
### Checklist

- [x] I have searched the [existing issues](https://github.com/streamlit/streamlit/issues) for similar feature requests.
- [x] I added a descriptive title and summary to this issue.

### Summary

`st.plotly_chart` accepts `**kwargs` but with the exception of the `config` parameter these are actually never used in our code. I think we should get rid of them. 


### Why?

Today, you can pass arbitrary `**kwargs` to `st.plotly_chart`, which, according to our documentation, gets passed through to Plotly's `plot()` function. However:

- That's not the case. We only extract a `config` parameter from `**kwargs` (see [here](https://plotly.com/python/configuration-options/)) and pass that through. Additionally, we extract `show_link` and `link_text` and put that into `config` if available, but according to our telemetry data, these parameters are basically never used. 
- The `plot()` function from Plotly mentioned in our docs is outdated. The modern alternative is `show()`. 
- Accepting arbitrary `kwargs` is messy. E.g. right now we're trying to add `width` and `height` to `st.plotly_chart` but some users are already setting these parameters through `kwargs`, probably because they think they get passed through to Plotly. While it doesn't cause any problem in this case, it's better to avoid such problems in the future. 

### How?

I'd suggest we:

- Mark `**kwargs` as deprecated and potentially remove it soon. I.e. this should raise a deprecation warning whenever you pass a parameter not explicitly supported. 
- Add `config` as an explicit parameter and say that this is the Plotly config dict, which is getting passed to the `show()` function.
